newsitem.title: BULGARIA: Bulgarian police seize pirated video production.
newsitem.headline: Bulgarian police seize pirated video production.

text.p: Bulgarian police have seized almost 2,000 illegal video cassettes worth some 15 million levs ($8,200) in a raid in Sofia as part of a crackdown on audio-visual piracy in which the Balkan country is ranked second only to China.
An Interior Ministry statement, carried by the state news agency BTA on Wednesday, said police had raided 63 shops, firms and traders who distribute video cassettes in the Bulgarian capital.
Some of the cassettes confiscated on Tuesday contained cartoons and pornographic films, the statement said.

Bulgaria's government, which took office in May, has vowed to crack down on this bootleg trade and police said they had seized pirated audio-visual products worth more than 1.5 billion levs in the first six months of the year.
The interior ministry said police had seized more than 200,000 illegal compact discs, 100,000 audio cassettes and more than 30,000 video cassettes this year.

Audio-visual piracy has flourished since the collapse of communism in 1989 and the International Federation of Phonographic Industry has said Bulgaria's production cost the European recording industry some $100 million a year.
Washington put Bulgaria on a "watch list" last October and the music industry urged Sofia to take tougher measures in protecting intellectual property rights.
Last month customs officers bulldozed more than 91,000 pirated CDs worth some $2 million in a bid to prove their determination to crack down on illegal production.
Bulgaria took its first piracy case to court last month but the defendant was acquitted for lack of evidence.
